name: Anonymous
com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Unironic COIN expert here

The TL;DR is that you defeat an insurgency by destroying their ability to draw support from the civilian population. This can a number of forms

>just put all the civilians in the effected area in camps (as in the Boer War or Malayan Emergency)
>use police/goons to identify guerilla supporters among the civilian population and physically eliminate them (as in Operation Phoenix during the Vietnam War)
>send small groups of special forces to live among the tribes and convince them to switch sides (as in the One Tribe at a Time strategy proposed in Afghanistan, and probably a bunch of ones I'm forgetting about)
>train the civilians in the combat zone into paramilitary patrols that are capable of resisting the insurgents on their own (as in the Combined Action Program in Vietnam, or the Rondas Campesinas in Peru)
>bribe important insurgent figures to switch sides (as in the Second Chechen War)

and possibly the most fun one

>infiltrate insurgents or just dress your guys up as insurgents, and then commit a bunch of horrific war crimes against the civilian population so that nobody supports them any more (as in the Algerian Civil War, or the Koevoet during the South African border war)

Note that if you don't solve the underlying political issue that led to the insurgency, another one will eventually sprout up (see: Guatemala, Algeria, Palestine, Iraq)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14302957
Is god corporeal? How would a being outside of our observable universe reach a noncorporeal hand into our universe to pick up a stone in a zero gravity enviroment with no up or down?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14302957
Yes. God binds Himself on multiple occasions, most famously his promise after the flood. He makes other promises of varying consequence and severity, and obviously operates within certain bounds more for the sake of consistency/justice/moral reasons than anything else.
Can God lift the stone, should He choose to renege on the promise? Also yes, though He is morally bound not to do so. While for imperfect beings like us this is a flimsy proposition, for God it'd be fairly certain.
Of course, arguendo, one could continue to demand specifications on how God is bound. Is He physically incapable of lifting the stone? Must God never be able to renege? Can God otherwise interact with the stone?
Omnipotence means that while He might be theoretically capable of lifting this stone under any circumstance, He could be practically incapable.
For a good analogy, one might want to study the law of sovereignty in constitutionally governed nations like the United States.

Not to denigrate Han Xin or anything, he certainly was better, but the starting position was slightly different in a two important ways:
1. Hanzhong was treated as the main population center and heart of Liu Bang's fief, whereas in Liu Bei/Shan's state the heart was further south in Ba and Shu with Hanzhong relatively depopulated by war. Zhuge Liang therefore faced a much harder logistical situation in supplying and maintaining forward positions.
2. In Liu Bang's time, the Guanzhong region was divided into of three separate states, making it much harder to maintain a coordinated defense. Zhuge Liang faced a Guanzhong region that was ruled under a single regime and could better field a unified defense.

Slavery proved a huge boon over other forms of labor like indentured servitude to these plantations. Not only could you work people, but you could buy and sell them, making even more money.

sub: Let's talk about Amerindian religious organizations
com:
I'll start with Incan religion, pic is the Vilaoma, often equated to a pope or high pontiff of the Inca state cult of the Sun, superior in rank to any other priest and being only second in command after the emperor. An early report of 1535 refers that while the Emperor was considered the "son of the Sun", the Vilaoma was the "servant or slave of the Sun".
Although, it is reported that at the beginning of Guayna Capac's rule, the position of Vilaoma was removed from office and Guayna Capac personally assumed the role of High priest of the Sun.
However, the name took importance again in the government of Manco Inca, after European contact, this Vilaoma, who like Manco and Paullo, supposedly was one of the hundreds of sons of Guayna Capac, took a leading role in Manco's rebellion, as the chief commander in the siege of Cusco, his real name isn't known, the chronicles speak of him as if Vilaoma was his personal name (making a distinction between the historical title, "the Vilaoma", and the right hand of Manco, Vilaoma), it was common to change names according to the stages of life, so this may be the case here.
Anyways, the name Vilaoma probably derives from the words: "Willay" which means to communicate, probably in relation to the sacred oracles or waka (super important for Incan religion), and his role as royal advisor, and "Oma" may come either from uma or head in Quechua or more probably oma/uma water in Aymara and specifically referring to the still existing province of Omasuyos (meaning water province), an area of intense religiosity in relation to the cult of Tunupa/Wiracocha, and just north of Tiahuanaco, where Manco Inca was supposedly born, and probably why he had more support from representatives of the Collasuyo (one of the 4 main divisions of the kingdom) than anywhere else.
In this drawing, he's seen with a chin adornment and a chacrahinca head insignia, both adornments were very characteristic of Collasuyu ethnic aristocracy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14303320
(cont.)
They obeyed one who commanded them, and they could not marry after they were determined to serve God in this life; they promised to obey the Vilahoma and his vicars, to respect the elders and to be loyal to the Inca and never to touch a woman in their life.
Many of these offered themselves as young boys and lasted in continence and virginity until old age. They walked gaunt, dressed in brown or black, with very long sleeves and hair cut to their ears like manes; they did not drink liquor; when they were in town, they walked in twos or threes, not in pairs, like religious, but one after the other. Many of these, or most of them, were eunuchs, which they call corasca, who either castrated themselves, in reverence of their gods, or were castrated by others, when were young boys, so that they would serve in this way of life.
When they went out into the squares and streets, they took with them all the people, who regarded them as saints, and they prayed publicly for the Inca and for the people, beat themselves with stones, knelt with tears, drew blood with flints, and even killed themselves by falling from the heights.
When these seemed to be already firm in their purpose and made good use of their way of life and penances, they would go with the permission of their Tocrico [a high Inca official], who was like their prelate, to the mountain or wilderness to live in solitude and close penance, and there they would keep the vows of the tito, who was also the tito of the Incas, they kept the vows of tito and hunicui which means chastity and obedience that they had promised (by means of a rite) and they added another vow of uscacuy which is poverty and villulluy, self-contempt of the poor beggar (willuy means "defenselessness") and they kept this punctually.

The people called these huancaquilli, that is, disinherited and detached from all riches, and withdrawn (from society) and there was even a time when the old sorcerers went to have another such solitude in the mountain.
There they contemplated the sun, the moon, the stars and reverenced them without ceasing. Also the mountains, the basins of the rivers, the rocks, served them as temples, oratories and sanctuaries. They slept on the ground, ate roots, drank rainwater, disciplined themselves with tightly knotted cords, and just as the ancient anchorites were once much visited by the faithful. So were they also visited by the indians. If they died, they were buried by the rest of their lonely neighbors with great weeping and superstitions.

>>14303992
Inca religion was principally centered around the worship of the wakas, which is a very vague term but basically were holy places, objects, or people, the power of the wakas resided in that they were oracles, and were consulted for pretty much everything, lots of decisions about war, administration and many other things went through the waka oracles, there were organized into a system of ritual lines or zeque which was emulated in hundreds of locations across the empire after the one in Cusco, which had over 400 wakas.
After conquering a nation, the Incas would take to Cusco the principal portable wakas and have them as leverage in case of a rebellion. Sometimes wakas were destroyed, and there were even people specialized in verifying that a waka still had power or that it was fake.
Other than that, among many others, the Incas worshipped Inti (Sun) and Wiracocha as their principal gods and erected lots of temples in honor of the Sun, each particular emperor could be more inclined to either of them and their worship was imposed over their vassals, not that it was much needed as many people already did worship them in some way or another, some didn't though, in the coast, the Chimu king questioned the Sun worship as in the hot desertic coast where he lived it brought droughts and famine, reasoning that his veneration was convenient for highland people but not for them. On rare occasions ancient local cults with their own independent clergy were left in place, and could even become favored wakas of certain emperors, this was pretty rare but it happened for Pachacamac and Catequil. But for its unfavorable predictions, the cult of Catequil would be eventually destroyed first by Wayna Qhapaq and later by Atahualpa who also planned on destroying Pachacamac.

name: Anonymous
com:
>The Kamakura shogunate decided to exile Nichiren to the island of Sado in the Sea of Japan. High government officials, however, planned to have him killed in secret. In the pre-dawn hours of the following morning, a group of soldiers took Nichiren to a place called Tatsunokuchi, on a beach near Kamakura. But just as they were about to carry out the order to behead him, a brilliant object appeared in the sky. As Nichiren described it later, “A brilliant orb as bright as the moon burst forth from the direction of Enoshima [a small island off the shore], shooting across the sky from southeast to northwest.” The soldiers, terrified, abandoned their attempt. This incident is known as the Tatsunokuchi Persecution.

>This event is extremely significant in the context of Nichiren’s lifetime teachings. He mentions it in The Opening of the Eyes, written in 1272, where he states: “On the twelfth day of the ninth month of last year, between the hours of the rat and the ox [11:00 p.m. to 3:00 a.m.], this person named Nichiren was beheaded. It is his soul that has come to this island of Sado and, in the second month of the following year, snowbound, is writing this to send to his close disciples.”

>The passage may be interpreted as follows: Nichiren as an ordinary person died, while the soul of Nichiren as the Buddha survived. This is a figurative indication that he had cast off his provisional identity or role as an ordinary person and revealed his true identity as the Buddha. In technical terms this is called “casting off the transient and revealing the true.” In this new role, Nichiren inscribed “my life [or more literally, soul] in sumi ink” in the form of the mandala known as the Gohonzon. With faith in the Gohonzon, Nichiren states, all people can manifest their innate Buddhahood, which is the meaning of “attaining Buddhahood in one’s present form or body” in his teachings. This concept is repeatedly referred to in The Record of the Orally Transmitted Teachings.

>>14303372
This is something that historians have been struggling with since the very beginning of historical scholarship. Herodotus, who is considered the first historian, was an ancient Greek who lived a generation after the Greco-Persian war. He was concerned about what would happen once living memory of the war was gone, so he just kind of went out and interviewed people about it, and whatever other stories they wished to tell him. He also traveled to the surrounding nations and wrote extensively about them as well. If you read his book you can see that he came up with a notion of ordering information based on the reliability of the speaker, and the plausibility of their statement, cross-referencing it with other things he knew. Primary accounts from people who personally witnessed events were the most reliable, then you move down to second hand stories, legends, and myth. So it's always been a problem, the best you can do is mitigate it by trying to aggregate sources, and understand the context in which they were written.

This is particularly a problem for ancient history, because of the small number of sources that survive. There's a nice essay about this in the Cambridge Illustrated History of China. The author talks about how in a history book that's a civilizational survey, people have an expectation that it's going to start at the beginning, and move chronologically from ancient times to the present. But so many of the sources we have about ancient times were written by people in later eras, so were colored by the politics and culture of that period. Even sources that are more close to the events described may be political propaganda from when they were written, and intentionally downplay what actually happened to further a particular political agenda unique to that moment in time. Just remember that people are the same, the same emotions and desires that everyone has today existed as a constant of human history.

Circassia (NWC) was allied with and a part of the Ottoman Empire. The Russian Empire first conquered the Northeast Caucasus in the mid 1700s (which was not a part of the Ottoman Empire) and then conquered the Northwest Caucasus in the mid 1800s. They conquered the Crimean Khanate in-between the two—first taking Budjak in 1770s and genociding the Budjak Tatars, and then taking the rest of the Crimean Khanate in the 1780s.

Russia genocided them became they wanted to monopolize access to the Black Sea there (which connects to the Mediterranean) and the agriculture on the adjacent lands. They did the same in Astrakhan and Volgograd oblasts (both in the Volga Delta basin / upper Caspian Sea) where they genocided the Volga Tatars.

Since Russia was ruled by a German monarchy since the 1700s, they brought in ethnic Germans as well as Baltic and Slavic people to settle the upper Black Sea coast and the upper Caspian Sea coast. Tatarstan today has a mixed Russian and Turkic population, but the areas to its south like Astrakhan and Volgograd have very few Turkic people. Similarly, there are very few Circassian and Abazin peoples in the NWC today while the Arshtin and Ubykh peoples are outright extinct.

Since Dagestan (NEC) is nowhere near as prime a location for agriculture as the regions further north along the Caspian Sea, nor did it have access to the open oceans like the Black Sea did, Russia never genocided them, nor did they move there in large numbers since the NEC is mostly mountainous.

>Kiri-sute gomen[1] (斬捨御免 or 切捨御免, "authorization to cut and leave [the body of the victim]") is an old Japanese expression dating back to the feudal era right to strike (right of samurai to kill commoners for perceived affronts). Samurai had the right to strike with sword at anyone of a lower class who compromised their honor.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsujigiri

>Tsujigiri (辻斬り or 辻斬, literally "crossroads killing") is a Japanese term for a practice when a samurai, after receiving a new katana or developing a new fighting style or weapon, tests its effectiveness by attacking a human opponent, usually a random defenseless passer-by, in many cases during nighttime.[1] The practitioners themselves are also referred to as tsujigiri.[1]
